{{Merge from|Casually Pepper Spray Everything Cop|discuss=Talk:Occupy UC Davis#Merger proposal|date=December 2011}} {{Use mdy dates|date=November 2011}} {{Infobox civilian attack |title = UC Davis pepper spray incident |image = OccupyUCD3.jpg |caption = UC Davis Police officer Lieutenant John Pike uses pepper spray on Occupy demonstrators. |location = [[Davis, California|Davis]], [[California]], [[United States|USA]] |target = [[UC Davis]] students |date = November 18, 2011 |time = 2:10 PM |timezone = Pacific |fatalities = 0 |injuries = 10 |weapons = [[Pepper spray|Police Issue Pepper Spray (Oleoresin Capsicum)]] |perps=UC Davis Police }} '''Occupy UC Davis''' is an ongoing series of [[Occupy Movement]] demonstrations at the [[University of California, Davis]]. It is distinguished from the off-campus but allied [[Occupy Davis]]. Occupy UC Davis gained international attention on November 18, 2011 after a video on YouTube went viral of University police [[pepper-spray]]ing a group of peaceful demonstrators as they were seated on a sidewalk.<ref>CS Monitor [http://www.csmonitor.com/USA/2011/1119/UC-Davis-pepper-spray-smear-tactics-Occupy-protests-face-rougher-response UC Davis Pepper-Sprays Protestors]</ref>
Police officers claimed that demonstrators had surrounded them and that they used the pepper-spray in self-defense.{{Citation needed|date=December 2011}} However, videos of the event did not support the claim that the non-violent protestors posed any threat to the officers. Consequently, two UC Davis police officers and UC Davis Police Chief Annette Spicuzza were placed on administrative leave while UC Davis student and faculty organizations are calling for the resignation of UC Davis Chancellor [[Linda P.B. Katehi]]. [[Mark Yudof]], president of the [[University of California]] system, has called for a review of all UC protocols for dealing with non-violent protestors.
The image of John Pike using pepper spray on the students become an internet meme, with the image appearing on many historically significant works of art, including Trumbull's Declaration of Independence and the cover of the Beatles' Sgt Pepper's Lonely Hearts Club Band.
==Background== Occupy UC Davis draws upon [[nonviolence|non-violent]] [[civil disobedience]] of the kind used in the [[American Civil Rights Movement]].{{Citation needed|date=November 2011}} [[Occupy Wall Street]] ('''OWS''') began on September 17, 2011, in New York City's [[Zuccotti Park]] in the [[Wall Street]] financial district with protests focused on social and [[economic inequality]], high unemployment, greed, as well as corruption, and the undue influence of corporationsâparticularly that of the [[financial services]] sectorâon government. The protesters' slogan ''[[We are the 99%]]'' refers to the growing [[income inequality in the United States|difference in wealth]] in the U.S. between the wealthiest 1% and the rest of the population. The protest since grew into a world-wide movement known as the [[Occupy Movement]].
[[Occupy Cal]] is an on-going series of protests at [[UC Berkeley]]. A major theme of the Occupy demonstrations at California public universities is the role of [[education]] in creating [[jobs]] and improving the quality of life of society as a whole, and the contrasting failure of the [[UC Regents]] and the [[California|State of California]] to honor commitments made in the California Master Plan for Higher Education. Recent 81% tuition increases for students, mandatory furloughs (including for professors), firings of lower-ranking workers (especially those working directly with students), and well-publicized raises for the highest paid administrators have further fueled discontent both within the [[University of California]] system (of which UC Davis is a part) and within the [[California State University]] system, which has also seen large tuition raises and consequent protests.
[[Occupy Davis]] (as opposed to Occupy UC Davis) was formed in response to police violence at Occupy Cal and other protests. Occupy Davis protestors occupied the city's Central Park in mid-October.<ref>{{cite news|last=Sakash|first=Tom|title=Occupy Davis chooses Central Park as its focus|url=http://www.davisenterprise.com/local-news/occupy-davis-chooses-central-park-as-its-focus/|accessdate=November 22, 2011|newspaper=Davis Enterprise|date=October 13, 2011|page=A5}}</ref>
====Police violence at Occupy Cal, protests in response at UC Davis==== {{ external media | align = right | width = | video1= [http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=buovLQ9qyWQ Police beat and arrest students at UC Berkeley], Nov 9 }}On November 9, students and professors at UC Berkeley began with a series of "teach-ins" around campus, a noon rally and march. Approximately 1,500 demonstrators attended the days' events. <ref name=10KGO>{{cite news|last=Hollyfield|first=Amy|title=Occupy Cal calm, but ready for showdown|url=http://abclocal.go.com/kgo/story?section=news/local/east_bay&id=8426365|accessdate=November 13, 2011|newspaper=KGO-TV|date=November 10, 2011}}</ref> Midday, protestors set up seven tents to symbolize their support for [[Occupy Movement]]. In response, law enforcement officials from UC Berkeley Police, the [[Alameda County Sheriff's Office]] and other UC Police officers in [[riot gear]] arrived to remove the seven tents from the protest site. <ref>{{cite news|last=Asimov|first=Nanette|title=Occupy Cal protesters vote to strike on Tuesday|url=http://www.sfgate.com/cgi-bin/article.cgi?f=/c/a/2011/11/10/MNH21LT6ND.DTL|accessdate=November 13, 2011|newspaper=San Francisco Chronicle|date=November 11, 2011}}</ref> <ref name=SF2>{{cite news|last=Asimov|first=Nanette|title=UC campus police move in on student protesters|url=http://www.sfgate.com/cgi-bin/article.cgi?f=/c/a/2011/11/10/BA861LSR8G.DTL|accessdate=November 13, 2011|newspaper=San Francisco Chronicle|date=November 10, 2011}}</ref>
Video footage of the afternoon confrontation showed police beating protesters with batons and dragging two protesters by the hair, one of whom was UC Berkeley English professor [[Celeste Langan]].<ref>{{cite news|last=Gollan|first=Jennifer|title=UC Berkeley Pledges to Investigate Police Response to Occupy Cal Protest|url=http://www.baycitizen.org/occupy-movement/story/uc-berkeley-pledges-investigate-police/|accessdate=November 13, 2011|newspaper=The Bay Citizen|date=November 11, 2011}}</ref> 39 protesters, including Langan, were arrested for charges including "resisting and delaying a police officer in the performance of their duties, and failure to disperse when given a dispersal order."<ref>{{cite news|last=Bowe|first=Rebecca|title=Occupy Cal makes its dramatic entrance|url=http://www.sfbg.com/politics/2011/11/10/occupy-cal-makes-its-dramatic-entrance|accessdate=November 13, 2011|newspaper=San Francisco Bay Guardian|date=November 10, 2011}}</ref>
The [[ACLU]] expressed "grave concerns" about the use of batons on protesters. The UC Student Association released a statement saying "UC Students are outraged by the brutal tactics used by the UCPD against students." <ref>{{cite news|last=Applegate|first=Jamie|title=Reactions to the police response to Occupy Cal on Nov. 9|url=http://www.dailycal.org/2011/11/13/reactions-to-the-police-response-to-occupy-cal-on-nov-9/|accessdate=November 13, 2011|newspaper=The Daily Californian|date=November 13, 2011}}</ref> In response to the police brutality and other perceived failings of [[Robert Birgeneau]] and the [[UC Regents]], the [[Occupy Cal]] General Assembly called for a general UC strike on November 15, 2011. Other student groups from around the state announced plans to join in the protest. On November 11, the [[UC Davis]] Faculty Association also voted to endorse the November 15 systemwide strike. <ref>[http://ucdfa.org/2011/11/11/dfa-endorses-occupy-cals-call-for-strike/ Davis Faculty Association Endorses Occupy Calâs Call for Strike]</ref> University Professor [[Bob Ostertag]] echoed these sentiments in a public letter about the earlier events at UC Berkeley, writing:<ref>[[Bob Ostertag]]. [http://www.huffingtonpost.com/bob-ostertag/uc-davis-protest_b_1103039.html Militarization of Campus Police], ''[[Huffington Post]]''</ref> {{quote|Chancellor [[Robert J. Birgeneau|Robert Birgeneau]] thus joins the likes of Bull Connor, the notorious segregationist and architect of the violent repression of the civil rights movement in Birmingham, Alabama, as some of the very few people who view the non-violent tactics of Martin Luther King as violent.}} The faculty of the UC Davis Department of English published a statement calling for "the disbanding of the UCPD and the institution of an ordinance against the presence of police forces on the UC Davis campus, unless their presence is specifically requested by a member of the campus community."<ref>[http://english.ucdavis.edu/ Department of English] accessed Nov 22, 2011</ref>
==Police violence at Occupy UC Davis== {{POV-section|date=November 2011}} {{external media | align = right | video1 = [http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Q09i3PKIf50 Cops Pepper Spray Passive Protesters ] (Associated Press) | video2 = [http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=hvnWShJp_2A UC Davis chancellor sorry for pepper spray incident ] (Reuters) }} On November 18, 2011, Chancellor Katehi ordered [[Occupy movement]] protesters on the UC Davis campus to remove their tents from the quad. The reason for this was based on University event policies that stated unless a permit was reserved, the use of tents was unlawful and could potentially create hazards for students over the weekend, when resources were limited.<ref>[http://www.cevs.ucdavis.edu/Public/]</ref> When a group of protestors engaged in [[nonviolence|nonviolent]] [[civil disobedience]] refused to remove their tents and staged a sit-in, campus police officers [[pepper spray]]ed them.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://edition.cnn.com/2011/11/20/us/california-occupy-pepperspray/index.html|title=California university launches inquiry into pepper spray of protesters|publisher=CNN|accessdate=November 20, 2011|date=November 21, 2011}}</ref> Eleven protesters received medical treatment; two were hospitalized.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.davisenterprise.com/local-news/crime-fire-courts/protests-again-gathering-steam-on-campus/|title=UCD to review pepper-spraying, clearing of protesters|publisher=Davis Enterprise|accessdate=November 19, 2011}}</ref><ref>{{cite news | newspaper=[[The Cleveland Leader]] | title=UC Davis Police Brutally Pepper Spray OWS Protesters Sitting Peacefully on Campus | url=http://www.clevelandleader.com/node/17846 | first=Julie | last= Kent | date= November 19, 2011 | accessdate =November 21, 2011}}</ref> Nathan Brown, assistant professor at UC Davis, said, "One of them, forty-five minutes after being pepper-sprayed down his throat, was still coughing up blood." <ref name="independent_adams">Guy Adams, [http://www.independent.co.uk/news/world/americas/outcry-over-chilling-campus-pepper-spray-use-6265203.html Outcry over 'chilling' campus pepper spray use], [[The Independent]], November 20, 2011</ref> The police have not responded to these claims.
According to police and university officials, the 35 or so officers present felt surrounded. One of the officers who used pepper spray was identified as Lieutenant John Pike.<ref>[http://www.huliq.com/10178/video-pepper-spray-aftermath-uc-davis-professor-demands-chancellors-resignation "Video In pepper spray aftermath"]</ref> Ten arrests were made.<ref name = âCSMâ>[http://www.csmonitor.com/USA/2011/1120/UC-Davis-pepper-spray-incident-goes-viral/%28page%29/2 Brad Knickerbocker, âUC Davis pepper spray incident goes viralâ, The Christian Science Monitor, November 20, 2011]</ref>. A demonstrator said that the police were encircled by the demonstrators. "A collective decision was made on the fly to just sit in a circle arms linked legs crossed, with police officers and "prisoners" in the middle because we didn't want them arresting only 3 of us. It wasn't fair that 50 of us were there, and only a few arrested who hadn't volunteered to be arrested. There was still one walkway open that the police were going to use to walk the arrestees out. I saw some friends of mine sit down there, and they were my friends, so I joined them. We linked arms, legs crossed."<ref>[http://boingboing.net/2011/11/20/ucdeyetwitness.html Xeni Jardin, "Interview with a pepper-sprayed UC Davis student"], BoingBoing.net, Nov 20. The demonstrator is identified as "W."</ref>
===Response=== Journalist [[Laura Flanders]] described the events as a "[[Bull Connor]] Moment," in reference to the Birmingham, Alabama leader who infamously deployed firehoses and attack dogs against peaceful protestors during the [[American Civil Rights Movement]].<ref>[http://www.pbs.org/wgbh/amex/eyesontheprize/story/07_c.html PBS's Eyes on the Prize segment, including video of Connor.][http://www2.nbc13.com/vtm/news/local/article/bull_connors_tank_returns_to_birmingham/39865/ Connor's Tank Returns to Birmingham]; Laura Flanders, Nov 19, 2011 "Up with Chris Hayes"</ref> Viewing footage of the events, political strategist [[Ron Christie]] described it as "excessive force" saying, "I wouldn't call that ''pepper-spray'', I'd say that was a ''pepper-hose''."<ref>[http://today.msnbc.msn.com/id/45401094/ns/msnbc_tv-hardball_with_chris_matthews/]</ref> Kamran Loghman, who helped develop pepper spray into a [[weapons-grade]] material with the [[Federal Bureau of Investigation]] in the 1980s, said, "I have never seen such an inappropriate and improper use of chemical agents."<ref name="seelye2011">Seelye, Katharine Q. (November 22, 2011). [http://www.nytimes.com/2011/11/23/us/pepper-sprays-fallout-from-crowd-control-to-mocking-images.html Pepper sprayâs fallout, from crowd control to mocking images.] ''[[New York Times]]''</ref>

Public Radio]]|accessdate=November 22, 2011|date=November 20, 2011}}</ref> Katehi appeared on CNN shortly after, demonstrating some remorse but ultimately defending her actions.<ref>{{cite 2011|date=November 20, 2011}}</ref> Katehi also called for creation of a task force to review the incident and report their findings and recommendations within 90 days.<ref>{{cite news |newspaper= |last1= Pringle | first2=Sam | last2=Quinones | date= November 19, 2011 | accessdate =November 21, 2011}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.kcra.com/r/29813746/detail.html|title=Task Force Created To Review Pepper Spray Incident|publisher=KCRA-TV|accessdate=November 19, 2011}}</ref> That evening, approximately 1,000 students and supporters participated in a silent protest against the calling for both the immediate resignation of the Chancellor and for an end to police removal of non-violent protestors from the campus: {{quote|Given the recent use of excessive force by police That body voted (with 99.5% consensus) to stage an education-wide general strike on Monday, November 28.<ref>[http://www.occupyucdavis.org/ "Occupy UC Davis Calls for a General Strike"]</ref> Katehi and State Assembly Speaker [[John A. On November 21, Katehi attended a large student protest, and after listening to their statements, said she was there to apologize.<ref name=stanton21>{{Cite web | last = Stanton | first = Sam | last2 = Sangree | first2 = Hudson | last3 = Fletcher | first3 = Ed | last4 = Lindelof | first4 = Bill | title = Chancellor Katehi apologizes to protesters for UC Davis pepper-spraying - Sacramento News - Local and Breaking Sacramento News | url = http://www.sacbee.com/2011/11/22/4072304/chancellor-katehi-apologizes-to.html | publisher = ''[[The Sacramento Bee]]'' | date = Nov. 22, 2011, last modified Nov. 23 | accessdate =November 26, 2011 }}</ref> On the following day, she stated that the police had gone against her specific orders to act peacefully when removing tents or equipment, and not to proceed if there were too many students, and she had not approved the police use of riot gear.<ref>{{Cite web | last = Stanton | first = Sam | title = UC Davis chancellor says police defied her orders when they used pepper spray on protesters - Wire - Lifestyle - bellinghamherald.com | url = http://www.bellinghamherald.com/2011/11/22/2282560/uc-davis-chancellor-says-police.html | publisher = [[The Bellingham Herald]] | date = Nov. 22, 2011 | accessdate =November 26, 2011 }}</ref><ref name=stanton21 /> At a town hall meeting, she told around 1,000 students, "I want to unequivocally apologize to the entire community for the appalling use of pepper spray. I will do everything in my power to make sure nothing like that ever happens again." She said, "My instructions were for no arrests and no police force. I explicitly directed the chief of police that violence should be avoided at all costs."<ref name="www.sacbee.com">{{Cite web | last = Chea | first = Terence | last2 = Lin | first2 = Judy | title = CA chancellor under fire for pepper-spray incident - Sacramento News - Local and Breaking Sacramento News | url = http://www.sacbee.com/2011/11/23/4076517/ca-chancellor-under-fire-for-pepper.html | publisher = Sacramento Bee | date = Nov. 23, 2011 | accessdate =November 26, 2011 }}</ref>
==Internet meme== {{main|Casually Pepper Spray Everything Cop}} The image of John Pike using his pepper spray has become an [[internet meme]]. The image has been pasted onto many historically significant works of art, including [[Trumbull's Declaration of Independence]] and the cover of the Beatles' Sgt Pepper's Lonely Hearts Club Band.<ref>{{cite news|title=The pepper-spraying cop gets Photoshop justice| author=Xeni Jardin| date=Wednesday 23 November 2011| publisher=The Guardian| url=http://www.guardian.co.uk/commentisfree/2011/nov/23/pepper-spraying-cop-photoshop-justice|accessdate=28 November 2011}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=Occupy Lulz| author=Xeni Jardin|date=20 November 2011|publisher=boingboing|url=http://boingboing.net/2011/11/20/occupy-lulz.html|accessdate=28 November 2011}}</ref>
The meme has relevance in public and political discourse surrounding the Occupy protests in North America. As of November 21, the meme was mentioned in more than 40,000 page references in [[Google]] search queries, and in online articles from the [[Huffington Post]], ''[[The Wall Street Journal]]'', and ''[[The Washington Post]]''. As of November 29, the website [http://KnowYourMeme.com KnowYourMeme.com], which collects and records memes and their metrics, had collected [http://knowyourmeme.com/memes/pepper-spray-cop-casually-pepper-spray-everything-cop/photos over 1,600 variations] and the number was still growing.
An article in ''The Washington Post'' dated November 21, 2011 identified the officer depicted in the images as Lt. John Pike of the UC Davis campus police. The Huffington Post quoted UC Davis chancellor, [[Linda P.B. Katehi]], as saying the officer had been placed on leave pending an investigation, though she did not mention the officer's name directly.<ref>{{cite news | first = Jason | last = Dearen | title = UC Davis Pepper Spray Incident Prompts Suspension Of Officers | url = http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2011/11/20/uc-davis-pepper-spray-inc_n_1104104.html | publisher = ''[[The Huffington Post]]'' | date = November 20, 2011 | accessdate = November 21, 2011 }}</ref>
The meme has sparked a public debate regarding the appropriate use of pepper spray. On Monday, November 21, 2011, [[Fox News]] commentator [[Megyn Kelly]] appeared on political talk show [[The O'Reilly Factor]] saying of pepper spray "itâs like a derivative of real pepper. Itâs a food product essentially."<ref>{{cite news | first = Justin | last = Bank | title = Megyn Kelly minimizes pepper spray; Should she test it out? | url = http://www.washingtonpost.com/blogs/blogpost/post/megyn-kellys-minimizes-pepper-spray-should-she-test-it-out/2011/11/22/gIQAXQyEoN_blog.html | publisher = ''[[The Washington Post]]'' | date = November 23, 2011 | accessdate = November 24, 2011 }}</ref> In response, a petition was published on political website [[change.org]] to have Megyn Kelly eat or drink a full dose of pepper spray on national television.<ref>{{cite news | first = Nick | last = Douglas | title = Fox News anchor Megyn Kelly: Eat or drink a full dose of pepper spray on national television. | url = http://www.change.org/petitions/fox-news-anchor-eat-or-drink-a-full-dose-of-pepper-spray-on-national-television | publisher = ''[[change.org]]'' | date = November 23, 2011 | accessdate = November 24, 2011}}</ref> As of December 4, the petition had close to 41,000 signatures.
The meme has spread worldwide with articles in the British press including ''[[The Guardian]]''<ref>{{cite news|title=The pepper-spraying cop gets Photoshop justice|author=Xeni Jardin|date=November 23, 2011|publisher=The Guardian|url=http://www.guardian.co.uk/commentisfree/2011/nov/23/pepper-spraying-cop-photoshop-justice|accessdate=28 November 2011}}</ref> and ''[[Daily Mail]]''.<ref>{{cite news|title=Pepper spraying The Beatles? Occupy protest cop becomes an internet craze|date=November 24, 2011|publisher=Daily Mail Online|url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/news/article-2065419/Occupy-protest-pepper-spraying-cop-John-Pike-internet-hit-thanks-Photoshop.html}}</ref>
